title: Why do Orthodox Jews wear big hats? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not all of us do. Sometimes I wear a baseball hat with one of my favorite National Parks, or something like a Stetson Cruiser or a Santa Fe. There’s no regulations about this- it’s cultural. I spent a significant amount of time in the U.S. west and my family is from Eastern KY. I went to an orthodox synagogue* one time with a friend to Louisville, KY. (The “big City” in eastern KY.) He was from N.Y. and Florida. He was sure I had the wrong address. He asked if there were Jews here. A man answered, well, “I am , but I’m not sure you are.” He was in overalls and a hat. It is cultural and is dictated by local norms. An excellent Book is “CoalField Jews: An Appalachian History” by Deborah Weiner.

Our dress is traditional and identifies us with particular subgroups within Orthodox Jewry. A careful observer can tell a lot about a person by the type of hat they wear and how they wear it. The shape of the brim, whether it is bent down or up, as well as the style help us to dress as our peers do (much like every other society on earth)
